awd_titl_txt: Novel Statistical Frameworks for Local Inference in Neuroscience of Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning to make decisions is important in almost all aspects of our lives. How humans learn is a topic of intense study in many diverse fields including psychology, linguistics, and the neurosciences. Learning to categorize is particularly crucial for humans and other animals in our interactions with our environments - whether it is a friend or a foe, edible or non-edible, the word /bat/ or /hat/ etc. As we learn to categorize information, our brain and behavior fundamentally change. These longitudinal trajectories evolve differently in different individuals and across brain systems. While recording and analyzing human behavior and neural function have become sophisticated, statistical methods for characterizing local similarities and differences in the underlying neural and behavioral process dynamics across individuals and groups are still emerging. This project aims to address this critical gap through the development of novel statistical frameworks for complex behavioral data on learning in adults. This collaborative project will provide trainees with experiences in a broad range of interdisciplinary topics.

A common theme underlying the statistical research undertaken in this project is the assessment of the local dynamic behavior of the learning processes - how similar or different these processes are, including especially how similarly or differently they might be influenced by the associated predictors, across learning stages and brain networks. Through innovative adaptation and amalgamation of classical ideas and recent advances in diverse areas in statistics, including sparsity inducing priors, tensor factorization techniques, functional data analysis methods, locally informative sampling strategies, etc., novel generic statistical frameworks and associated computational machinery for local inference in longitudinal settings will first be developed. This frameworks will then be adapted to specific models for neural learning processes. The principal investigators will use carefully designed learning experiments in one domain of research - how adults learn novel speech categories and theories to validate the results obtained by the new statistical models. While human speech learning is an interesting and well-studied problem on its own, insights gained from this application are generalizable to other domains of studies that involve human learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Auditory processing and learning play critical roles in our lives. While human behavioral and neuroimaging studies have become increasingly sophisticated, there remains a lack of robust statistical methods to characterize systematic local similarities and differences in the underlying process dynamics across individuals and groups. This project aimed to address some of these gaps by developing novel statistical techniques to assess perceptual and neural processes involved in auditory processing and learning, providing new insights into these processes, and how they vary and evolve.

 

The first aims of this project focused on new methods for understanding the perceptual mechanisms underlying auditory category learning from behavioral data.

 

Drift-diffusion models, which simulate evidence accumulation in the brain via latent diffusion processes, are widely used computational tools for inferring categorization processes from behavioral proxies such as response times and accuracies. However, much of the previously existing literature focused on binary alternatives and simple study designs, which rarely capture the real-world complexity of category learning, where individuals seldom distinguish only between two exemplars. Moreover, the relationships between exemplars evolve throughout the learning process. Previously existing statistical methods were insufficient to address these complexities. To overcome these limitations, we developed novel longitudinal drift-diffusion mixed models for multi-category learning, providing a robust framework for studying more complex categorization processes. Our analysis provided novel insights into how novel auditory categories are learned over time and how they vary between good and bad learners.

 

Even though fitting drift-diffusion models requires data on both response categories and response times, response accuracy is often the primary metric used by behavioral scientists to describe human learning, overlooking response times. Moreover, in many practical scenarios, such as online experiments during the COVID-19 pandemic, accurately recording response times may not be feasible. The question whether drift-diffusion parameters can be recovered from accuracy data alone is therefore an important one but had never been addressed before. In this project, we explored this question. We noted that a new class of inverse-probit drift-diffusion models for response categories alone can be easily obtained by integrating out the response times, now considered latent, from our joint model for response categories and response times before. This marginal model, however, introduces significant statistical challenges, including identifiability issues that prevent the recovery of all parameters from the original joint model. By carefully addressing these issues, we developed a robust framework that can capture the general trends underlying learning based on data on response categories alone.

 

The final aims of this project focused on new methods for inferring undirected and directed brain networks involved in auditory processing, both in general and in response to stimuli, from neuroimaging data.

 

One of the main tools we use is called a graphical model, which helps map out two-way relationships between several variables. Previous methods to analyze this kind of data were slow and complicated, particularly when handling large amounts of information. In one of our works in this project, we created a general new method, which we called the "precision factor model”, that works faster and more efficiently, even when analyzing thousands of variables at once. We took this idea further by creating a method for if the data aren’t normally distributed which is often the case with neuroimaging data. Using this method, we found strong connections between specific areas of the brain involved in auditory processing.

 

Another challenge in brain research is figuring out how brain activity flows over time between different regions. To do this, we used a technique called Granger causality analysis, which helps reveal the direction of brain activity flow (i.e., which region influences another). Previously existing approaches for this kind of analysis worked only for small data sets and group-level inference, whereas our new methods can handle much larger data sets, capturing the important details, and enabling more accurate and efficient analyses of directed brain networks, both at the group and individual levels.

 

To date, the project has produced eight peer-reviewed publications, and several more manuscripts in progress. All the statistical methodologies developed have been made publicly available through open-source code. Significant efforts were also dedicated to developing user-friendly R packages, with one already available on the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN) and several others currently in preparation. The project also provided training opportunities for multiple graduate students, undergraduates, and postdoctoral researchers. Those working on the statistical side were exposed to collaboration-driven methodological research and trained in a wide range of statistical areas, including conditionally autoregressive models, drift-diffusion models, partition models, hidden Markov models, hidden Markov random field models, longitudinal mixed models, mixture models, spline models, tensor decomposition models, and vector autoregressive models. Similarly, students and postdocs in auditory neuroscience gained experience in applying these advanced statistical models to their research.
